image.caption:
Kwe’(Hello). Everyone is welcome to use this design for free to create any products for awareness as long as it’s not for ‘monetary gain’; the image will not be ‘altered’ in any way; or will be used in conjunction with another company or organizations logo. The artist has no products or merchandise with this design on it available for purchase. Thank-you(Wela’lin) for support.

Hummingbirds Design Description:
In this Every Child Matters Design, Hummingbirds symbolize our family and ancestors coming back to give us messages, and to let us know their spirits are still alive. There are continuous Mi’kmaq double curves displayed to show we are all connected spiritually to the land and each other. Msit No’kmaq(All My Relations-We Are All Connected).

image.alt_text: Photo by Discover Charlottetown in Prince Edward Island with @trishab223, @w.yonnab__, and @lnuey.ca. May be an image of one or more people and outdoors.
image.caption:
Happy National Indigenous Peoples Day 🧡

Today we honour & celebrate the original inhabitants of Prince Edward Island, the Mi’kmaq, who called the island Epekwitk, which means “lying in the water.” For over 12,000 years, they have been on the Island’s land and waterways, honouring and preserving the natural way of life. 

Epekwitk history includes horror and heartbreak, with the takeover and occupation of Mi’kmaq land, the largest Acadian Expulsion taking place across the Charlottetown harbour, slavery by government leaders, bigotry and racism. But this history also includes outstanding people and events, with justice warriors, storytellers, and other artists ensuring the voices of Mi’kmaq and Black people, women, and others were heard.

It is important that we see a fuller picture of Charlottetown’s history and explore various perspectives, including the injustices at play, and those who did not have a seat at the table at the time of Confederation (and many other points along the way). 

There is much, much work to be done and a great place to dive in today is over @lnuey.ca (link in bio) - they work tirelessly to spread awareness, educate, engage, govern, negotiate, and provide resources so we may all live more peacefully on this great land. They have lots of resources to help you learn about the issues at play—both throughout our history and those that sadly carry on today. 

May we continue to do our part to be better allies, friends, stewards, inhabitants, and visitors of this beautiful place we know and love.

We see you. We honour you. We thank you. 🍃

Photo: @trishab223 
Model: @w.yonnab__

image.alt_text: Photo by Melissa Peter-Paul in Abegweit First Nation.
image.caption:
I haven’t done any quillwork for six months. I figured today would be a good day to pick up my art again. On this day 17 years ago my Grammy Mary Jane Jadis passed away. It was a day I will never forget and also it was my first day of grade 12. 

I honour my grandmother in everything that I do; she was the most resilient woman I knew. She was a talented Mi’kmaw Artist and she paved the way for me and many other artists. 

It felt so good to pick up my art again. 

Wela’lin Grammy, I love and miss you so much. I’m going to end my day with some tea and sweets. ❤️ #mikmaq #mikmaqquillwork #melissapeterpaulart #epekwitk #quillwork #mikmaw

image.alt_text: Photo by Kirsten Malone on September 30, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and body of water.
image.caption:
September 30th has been declared truth and reconciliation day in Canada. 

Today is not a holiday, it's not a day off work or school, it's a day to educate yourself, to remember, to support and respect Indigenous Canadians.

Learn about the truth and reconciliation act. 
Learn about the missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls.
Learn about the horrors of residential schools.
Learn about systemic racism.
Learn about the racist Indian act that stripped Indigenous people of their rights, freedoms, and culture. 
Learn where the reserves are in your communities, what bands live in your area, and what First Nations land you stand on. 

It's time we Learn the truth, the real hard truth, and start making amends for our past and present mistakes.

For more than 11,000 years, people have lived in Mi'kma'ki which is currently home to 30  Mi'maq Nations, 29 of them located in Canada and including all of Nova Scotia and PEI, and large areas of Newbrunswick, Newfoundland, and the gaspé peninsula. 

The name Mi'kmaq means "my kin-friends." 

What Indigenous  land do you live on?

Almost 50 years old and I look like a beast that is younger/healthier than I did in my early 40's. Age is just a number 

Kesaluloq aq Wela'lioq!! 😁💪

image.alt_text: Photo by Nadia Kaqtikew E’pit George in Toronto, Ontario. May be an image of one or more people.
image.caption:
WELCOME WELCOME 🤗 
It’s story time!

Just shooting a hello to all my new followers 👋🏽

Life has been so busy and I’ve been meaning to get to this, I want to thank you for joining in my life journey. 

As you get to know me you’ll find I’m a little bit of everything under the sun all wrapped up into one 😝

But here are some facts to get you started:

My Name in my bio translates to “Thunder Woman” in Mi’kmaq. It’s been told to me that Thunder beings are messengers, which makes a lot of sense for me 💜 I was gifted my name, clan and colours this year and I still feeling the weight of responsibility to myself, my people and my elder. 

My astrological sun sign is: Sagittarius ♐️ and moon is Capricorn ♑️… I’m way more Sag, but definitely have my moon in me

I was born in Guelph, Ontario and most of my childhoood was spent there. My teen years and young adult life was spent all over Simcoe County, and I’m now based in Toronto.

My favourite foods are seafood, sushi, and of course too many native dishes to mention.

I’m a mom of 1 son (21 years old) and my fur baby @misslolaloveless 

My hobbies are: Hiking, traveling, eating donuts and being ridiculous 

My favourite colour is deep purple, but I tend to wear a lot of neutral colours. 

For more information about me feel free to visit my website and have a look around ☺️ Link is in bio 🥰

Nmu’ltes (see you all soon)
.
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Emily Critch in Galerie Sans Nom. May be art.
image.caption:
My exhibition between the rocks and flowers, i think of you opened today at @galeriesansnom. Thank you so much to their amazing team for installing my work and making this happen in the pandemic, I have so much gratitude 💖 If you're in Moncton, NB it's open til March 11🌟
.
.
between the rocks and flowers, i think of you is an exhibition by Emily Critch that considers her inherited histories from her home territory of Elmastukwek, Ktaqmkuk (the Bay of Islands, Newfoundland). Employing intimate and labour-intensive processes of creation like printmaking and stitching, she honours the lands and waters in Elmastukwek where her ancestors lived. She mediates her embodied family histories, memories and experiences through repetitive modes of image creation. In each detailed constellation of indelible flowers against the rocks, she uses repetition and the multiple as a method of participating in cultural transmission, storytelling, and remembering. The work from this exhibition was produced during a year-long residency as the 2020-21 Don Wright Scholar at @st_michaels_printshop, with generous support from the 2020 @vanlcarfac Cox & Palmer Pivotal Point Grant and ArtsNL.

#lnu #mikmaq #ktaqmkuk #printmaking #printmedia #photopolymer #screenprinting  #textiles #nlarts

image.alt_text: Photo by Mi'kmawey Debert Cultural Ctr on October 25, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'ভ Artwork by Gerald Gloade MI'KMAQ WIKEWIKU'S HISTORY MONTH OCTOBER'.
image.caption:
Saqmaq (Chiefs), Wampum and the role of the Putu's. 
 
Saqmaq were, and are, sovereign representatives of their communities. When gathering with neighbours and other Nations, Saqmaq were messengers for their people. 
 
Wampum belts were used by the Putu's, as well as others, to record events which were then interpreted when necessary. The most important decisions were recorded in Wampum and carried by oral histories. 
 
The Putu's is a member of the Santé Mawio’mi (or Grand Council) who would assist the Nation with remembering key events and agreements. Always, our agreements sought to protect Netukulimk and our ways of life. 

To learn more about this year's History Month theme, view the poster at the link in our bio.
.
.
.

image.caption:
🧡 The land is alive yet we treat it as something that is consumed and sold. 

May we acknowledge the pain and suffering colonial settlers have brought to this land, Indigenous peoples and children. 

May we acknowledge the children who died while attending residential schools and the survivors, families and communities still affected by the residential school system.

May we open up to the truth. 

May we reconcile relations and raise awareness about colonization and its ongoing effects on Indigenous peoples.

Today, and every day, I acknowledge that myself and Speyeral Beauty operates on the sacred land of Mi’kma’ki, the ancestral and unceded territory of the Mi’kmaq People. 

Wela'lin ~ Thank You

🧡 Jess

Artwork by Alanah @morning.star.designs

image.alt_text: Photo by Marcus Gosse in Stephenville, Newfoundland and Labrador. May be an illustration.
image.caption:
Available For Purchase
Title: “Spirit of the Eel(Katew)”
Medium: Acrylic on Acid Free Card Stock
Size: 8.5 x 11 inches
Price: $280 (Free Shipping Anywhere In Canada)
Date Completed: 2021
Description:  This painting titled “Spirit of the Eel(Katew)” displays an eel(katew) swimming around the Mi’kmaq Star. The eel(katew) has always been sacred to the Mi’kmaq. In times when there was no food to gather, we had the eel to help us survive. The floral motives revolving around the circle represents community connectedness, and how the eel(katew) has helped so many communities throughout Mi’kma’ki(Mi’kmaq Territory). It has always been here for us: providing survival, sustenance, and support. I would like to honour and celebrate its spirit. Wela’lin katew for always being there to help my ancestors survive. 
Msit No’kmaq(All My Relations-We Are All Connected).

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Hockey Indigenous on January 06, 2022 tagging @_alexanderchristmas. May be an image of one or more people and text.
image.caption:
Introducing Alexander Christmas, Mi'kmaw Forward from Membertou First Nation, Nova Scotia who is currently playing for the Sydney Rush of the Nova Scotia U18 Hockey League. 🪶🏒

Alexander has always played with an edge that helps his team and sees the ice really well. Prior to playing in the top midget leagues, Christmas played with the Cape Breton Cougars for two years in the Nova Scotia U15 Major League where he registered 27 goals, 30 assists in 63 games for a total of 57 points. Christmas also had a 5 games stint in the Nova Scotia U16 AAA Hockey League where he scored 3 goals. He has been playing with Sydney Rush of the NSU18HL for two seasons where he accumulated 24 goals, 33 assist for a total of 57 points in 51 games played. Christmas was also named to the 2020/21 Rookie All-Star Team.

Alexander Christmas was selected in the 9th round, #160 overall by Acadie-Bathurst Titan in the 2021 QMJHL Entry Draft!

We wish you the best of luck, Alexander! Keep following the COVID protocols and keep your head high! Keep up the amazing work!!🙌🏽

image.alt_text: Photo by Jesse Benjamin in Dalhousie University. May be an image of one or more people and outdoors.
image.caption:
QUESTION…how do you define:

1️⃣ Health❓
2️⃣ Being fit/in shape❓
3️⃣ Wellness ❓

I think about this a lot and how obscure or catch-all these terms can be, yet we also use them on the daily and are constantly striving towards them, yet we don’t always have a clear idea of what they really look like 🤷🏽‍♀️ How do you know when you have “achieved” health?? 

Curious to hear what others ideas are 🙏🏽

#pondering #healthylifestyle #healthandwellness #indigenous #mikmaq #fancyshawldancer

image.alt_text: Photo by L'nuey PEI on October 01, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'HAPPY TREATY DAY!'.
image.caption:
Treaty Day commemorates the signing and significance of the Peace and Friendship Treaties of the 1700s. 

It must be remembered that while these Peace and Friendship Treaties were entered into, the Mi’kmaq were never conquered, and never surrendered, gave up or ceded their land. Mi’kma’ki is still Mi’kmaq territory, and the Peace and Friendship Treaties serve as a foundation for the relationship of the Mi’kmaq and all citizens of the region.

To learn more on Peace and Friendship Treaties, visit http://lnuey.ca/treatyday/

Thunder beings⠀
⠀
@nadiageorgeofficial & I out here being exactly who we are.⠀

When you’re brought together with your spirit sister you lean in and listen to the alignment.⠀
⠀
I’m excited to align with an Indigenous sister who shares different lived experience, yet also similar. ⠀
⠀
Aligning with others beyond trauma is important to me. I want to lean into celebrating our cultures while learning from and with one another.⠀
⠀
We understand we carry a message within us that others can relate to & we’re coming together to ensure others feel heard, seen & not alone in their journey.

image.alt_text: Photo by Mi'kmawey Debert Cultural Ctr on October 22, 2021. May be a cartoon of outdoors, tree and text.
image.caption:
The Mi’kmaw practice of sharing is one way the culture honours the interdependence of life. While in some cultures sharing is seen as an act of generosity, in Mi’kmaw culture sharing is a deeply-rooted practice. Great respect is given to someone who shares what they have with others.
This practice of sharing is often called reciprocity in English. However, it is not just about sharing physical things; it is also about sharing one’s time, prayers or knowledge. In short, it’s about sharing life.

To learn more, visit the Mi'kmaq History Month website at the link in our bio.
.
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Marcus Gosse in Stephenville, Newfoundland and Labrador.
image.caption:
Title: “Coastal Life”
Medium: Acrylic on Blue Acid Free Card Stock
Size: 8.5 x 11 inches
Sold
Date Completed: 2021
Description:  This painting titled “Coastal Life” displays two seals(waspu) embracing the water, their environment, and each other. They are also supporting their culture by keeping the fishing shacks from falling into the ocean. It is important for us to support our culture; support each other; keep our waters clean; take only what we need; and preserve our land and culture for future generations. 
Msit No’kmaq(All My Relations-We Are All Connected).

image.caption:
Title: “Family Spirit”
Medium: Acrylic on Acid Free Card Stock
Size: 8.5 x 11 inches
Sold 
Date Completed: 2021
Description:  This painting titled “Family Spirit” displays an eel(katew) family having each other’s back, and supporting one another. Both eels have continuous curve designs to show family and community connectedness.  Eels symbolize endurance and fortitude. Their “Family Spirit” shows us that when we support each other, and stick together, there is nothing in life that can hold us back. 
Msit No’kmaq(All My Relations-We Are All Connected).

“We honour our ancestors by honouring each other”.

image.caption:
Tips for closing a grounding session 💜  I think you’ll like my last “At Home Tip” (read till end) 😊

Finding some humour in your day is the best think you can do for yourself.

After doing grounding work with clients. I do my best to get them laughing at the end of sessions. Not only does it help them, but it also helps me as a Therapist to be ready and present for my next session. 

Here are some at home tips:

•Read a funny story
•Watch a funny show
•Talk to a friend about “remember that time when”
• Listen to a funny podcast 
• watch silly/funny ticktock or insta reels
• or laugh at this photo of me laughing 😂 

Have a super hilarious and ridiculous day 💜
📸: @ymaphoto 
.
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Per Ivar ✍️ Colorizer on January 11, 2022. May be an image of one or more people and people standing.
image.caption:
Some of my ancestors from the village of  Máze, in Kautokeino.

I found this photo in the facebook group of old photos from Máze, and couldn't resist trying to colourise this photo that was unknown to me, despite the low quality of the photo.  After all, this is my ancestors! 

Photographer is unknown to me, and it was not mentioned in the fb group either. . 

In the front, my great grandparents NIls and Inger (Hætta)Turi. I do believe that it is their daughter ( my grandmother) that is standing to the left of them with a child in a cradle (komse/gietka) I think it is one of my eldest uncles or aunts in the cradle.

This means it must be around 1910 - 1912.

Many of the others gathered around here, are their family members, like the tall man to the right, Ture Nilsen Turi.

They had recently arrived from Newfoundland in Canada, where they had been for two years in a reindeer project (1908 - 1910). There they were joined with the Somby family, where my grandfather also were, and I like to think that it was there they kind of learned to know each other. They, my grandparents, got married in 1911.
The Newfoundland trip was rough. The reindeer died from a disease, and my grandfather got snowblind during the winter in the Newfoundland mountains.

The Somby family had good help from native mi'kmaq guide Mattie Mitchell during the project. 

#colourmypast #colouryourpast #colorizedphoto #colourisedphoto #masi ##kautokeino #sapmi #sápmi #mikmaq #newfoundland #Nilsturesenturi #somby

image.alt_text: Photo by MMNA in New Brunswick. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and text that says 'SABRINA POLCHIES #MMIWG WG'.
image.caption:
Repost from @nalgonapositivitypride
•
Reposted from @bigkatdaddy Sabrina Polchies was a 22 year old #Mikmaq woman from #Elsipogtog #FirstNation in New Brunswick and is described by her family as a loving and compassionate young woman. Mary Polchies said she received a phone call from her daughter the day she died, on July 2, 2010, and she could hear men yelling abusive and racist comments at her before the line went dead. Sabrina’s body was subsequently found on July 5, 2010 in #Salisbury #NewBrunswick and initially, the case was treated as suspicious. It should also be noted that her cellphone was found in the dumpster a few days later. Upon the discovery of alcohol and drugs in Sabrina's system, the #RCMP ruled that there was “no foul play”.⁠⁠
⁠.
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠

image.alt_text: Photo by Kendra Felicity Wheeler, BMus in St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador. May be an image of one or more people.
image.caption:
I’m not a very angry person in general. I can get frustrated, upset, but I am not often angry. Right now, though, I feel pure fury when I think of those 215 children in Kamloops.

My family was lucky to avoid residential schools, but we paid a huge price. We hid, and the cost of hiding was our religion, our language, our traditions. We assimilated to avoid persecution, and it has caused many people like me immense grief. We grieve the loss of our culture and the loss of our people.

I’ve often felt like I was not “indigenous enough” to consider myself indigenous, but I am here to represent those who lost their culture because of Canada’s awful treatment of First Nations people throughout  history and presently. It is because of residential schools, discriminatory laws, and violence toward indigenous people, that my family, my ancestors, and many people like me have lost our connection to such important aspects of our culture.

I hope these children can truly rest peacefully now that we know a little bit more about the injustices they faced.
.
.
. 📸: @findingjulianne 
.
.
.
.
.
.

image.caption:
#Repost @projectmosaicllc 
---
When I worked with teens, I took a group to the Denver March Powwow. One person said they weren't sure why the drum beat made them feel so good but also sad because they didn't know if their late Native grandma would be ashamed that this was their first powwow. No way, she's super proud of them for being called to the circle. 

Repost • @somewhere_under_the_rainbow ✨A gentle reminder for all of us who never grew-up on a rez, haven't tasted the wonder that is fry-bread, don't have access to our language. for all of us who still speak to our grandmothers in the spirit realm, interpret the signs of animals, have dreams that were past realities. for those of us with mixed heritages. for those of us still learning what it means to be us. to be us in a world not made for us. A gentle reminder. (The Ancestors asked me to share.)✨

📍Turtle Island

image.alt_text: Photo by Sehmat Suri | Canadian Blogger in K'jipuktuk with @larissa_speaks, @notoriouscree, @indigenous_baddie, @nikkilaes, @mikmaqangel, @killaatencio, @shinanova, @decolonizemyself, @wetsuweten_checkpoint, and @junnygirldecolonized. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'EVERY CHILD ATTERS'.
image.caption:
#EveryChildMatters 🧡

TW: Residential Schools •

I am a settler on Indigenous land in Canada, and today, I stand in solidarity with the Indigenous community to mourn the loss of hundreds of Indigenous children whose bodies have been found in unmarked graves at residential schools across Canada.

Residential schools in Canada ran between the 1870s and 1997, where 150,000 Indigenous children were forcefully taken from their families and placed in Church-run and government-funded schools. They were forced to learn English, convert to Christianity, and made to abandon their culture and beliefs. They were physically, mentally, and sexually abused, often malnourished, and severely mistreated. These institutions are NOT a thing of the distant past. The last one closed in 1997. I was 1 year old.

At the end of May 2021, the bodies of 215 Indigenous children, some as young as 3, were found in unmarked graves at the former Kamloops Indian Residential School in BC. Today, only two months later, that number sits at 1500, and unfortunately, it’s only growing. This trauma is now carried by the Indigenous community, as they fight the Canadian government for the right to their own land and equitable resources.

I would like to take this opportunity to share some resources and calls to action. This is by no means a comprehensive list, and if you have more resources to share, please put them in the comments!

🧡 Follow Indigenous creators: The most important voices to hear are those of the Indigenous community. Creators I personally follow are @mikmaqangel, @nikkilaes, @shinanova, @notoriouscree, @indigenous_baddie, @killaatencio, @larissa_speaks, @junnygirldecolonized, @decolonizemyself, and @wetsuweten_checkpoint.
🧡 Read the 94 Calls to Action put forward by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada: This report provides views and actions the Canadian government must take for reconciliation with our Indigenous communities.
🧡 Donate to the Indigenous Residential School Survivors Society: These donations are tax-deductible.
🧡 Have the conversation: Talk to your family and friends about what’s happening, share resources, and commit to learning.

#NoPrideInGenocide

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Rachel Otis Therapy, M.A. on November 24, 2021 tagging @indigenousrising, @nativewomenswilderness, @indigenouspeoplesmovement, and @decolonizemyself. May be an image of text that says 'INDIGNENOUS SIBLINGS: @somewhere_under_the_rainbow "THANKS- TAKING" A DAY TO RECLAIM WHAT WAS NEVER GIVEN AWAY BY OUR ANCESTORS & CAN NEVER BE STOLEN BY CURRENT COLONIZERS'.
image.caption:
✨oh sweet Indigenous sibling; please put your hand in mine so we may walk or roll into the next millennium together. no matter our mother tribe, may we put our differences aside to be in a clan of our own making...✨

✨ I can hear our ancestors chuckling now, their laughter deep & rolling like thunder claps: "our children, it's not about putting differences aside, it's about coming together to celebrate them. it's about relishing what makes us different; reveling in it with awe, curiosity & respect. it's about creating new traditions in honor of the old ones. it's honoring the inner elder & child within us all."✨

✨In my house we called this "holiday" Thanks-taking for as long as I can remember & today I'm sharing what that can mean for all of us (allies included - it's time to eff with the paradigm, it's time to get uncomfortable, it's time to make your own sacrifices).✨

🙏🏽Wela'lin🙏🏽

📍Wabanaki Confederacy

image.alt_text: Photo by CBC Nova Scotia in Nova Scotia. May be an image of one or more people, outdoors and text that says 'Nova Scotia to host North American Indigenous Games in 2023 Postponed games will bring 3D archery, lacrosse and other sports to Halifax and Millbrook'.
image.caption:
The 2020 games got cancelled by COVID-19, but it was just announced that the games will be held in Nova Scotia in July 2023.
.
The games will feature 16 sports including 3D archery, which places the sport in nature where participants shoot at three-dimensional targets instead of flat ones.
.
The games will also honour those harmed by residential schools and the children who died there, the chair of the hosting society said.
.
The games give participants “something positive to focus on and to celebrate young people and their futures,” Fiona Kirkpatrick-Parsons.
.
To read more the games and cultural events, click on the link in our bio ⬆️
.
.
.

FYI…proper term for an outfit worn by a dancer at a powwow is:

👉🏽REGALIA👈🏽

There are many different styles of regalia just as there are different styles of dance. And every individual will have a different story to their own regalia.

With Halloween coming up this is your friendly reminder that our culture is never a costume ❤️

image.alt_text: Photo by Cheekbone Beauty Cosmetics INC on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'gina'masuti [ni [gi-naa-ma-su-di] Mi'kmaq education knowledge, lesson'.
image.caption:
Every child has the right to a proper education. 

We recognize the obstacles our children face at school. The assurance of quality, safety, and comfort of First Nations education is significantly less than other schools across the country. Cultural discrimination creates barriers for our children to succeed as they face less opportunities and funding compared to other children.

Giving back to our community is a fundamental part of Cheekbone's mission. We’re proud to continue donating to several different organizations that help support equitable opportunities for the next generation to grow up safely at home, remain healthy, balanced, receive a proper education, and feeling proud of who they are. 

Happy September! 🍎 Let’s use this month to amplify our teachings. Our stories. Our vision.

#WordWednesday #NativeLanguage #education #equality #mikmaq #indigenouslanguage #makeupwithmeaning #CheekboneBeauty

(Sources: Mi’kmaq Online)

image.alt_text: Photo by Marcus Gosse in Stephenville, Newfoundland and Labrador. May be an image of bird.
image.caption:
Very thankful to The Rooms Provincial Art Gallery for purchasing the painting “Free Spirit” - Grey Jay (Whiskey Jack) for their permanent collection. Also, a big thanks to The Leyton Gallery of Fine Art for assisting with the acquisition, and all their support. 

Title: “Free Spirit” - Grey Jay (Whiskey Jack) 
Spirit Bird Collection
Medium: Acrylic on Canvas
Size: 16" X 20"
Description: I titled this painting of a Grey Jay “Free Spirit” because they seem free from all ‘worldly’ concerns; they pave their own path and fly to the beat of their own drum. Free spirits do not enjoy being controlled or restricted in any way, and value physical and emotional freedom above everything else in life. Grey Jays are relaxed, cultivated, display courage, wisdom, bravery, and believe in total non-conformity. Grey Jays remind me of most of my camping, painting, and fishing adventures, because they always showed up for my food from my “mug ups” and “boil ups”.

image.alt_text: Photo by Kendra Felicity Wheeler, BMus in St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador with @maskawitehew. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, outdoors and text that says 'INDIGENOUS'.
image.caption:
It is the first ever National Day for Truth and Reconciliation. I challenge everyone to educate themselves on the injustices indigenous people in Canada have faced for generations.
Honour the lives of those who did not survive these injustices and celebrate the lives of those who are still here. This is just the tip of the iceberg.

Wabanaki Double Curve medallion and earring set, inspired by the O’halloran coat (1841) 

I’d love for this set to find its home with a wabanaki person, so I ask that if that’s not you, you step back and allow this item to go to the nations it belongs to. 🖤

The earrings are made with size 11 Charlotte cuts. Backed with moosehide on 14k gold hooks. The beadwork measures 3 inches by 2.25 inches, and hang 4.5 inches including the hooks. 

The medallion is made with size 11 Charlotte cut beads, and antique size 15 alabaster beads in the leaf border. The edging features size 15 24 k gold beads. The medallion measures 4.5 inches across, and the beaded rope measures 31inches (not including the ties. 

This set is made of many days of work and expensive premium beads

image.alt_text: Photo by L'nuey PEI on September 28, 2021. May be an image of grass and text that says 'L'NUEY CELEBRATES TWO YEARS OF MOVING TOWARDS A BETTER TOMORROW'.
image.caption:
L’nuey Celebrates Two Years! 

September 28th, 2021, marks the two-year anniversary of the launch of L’nuey: the Mi’kmaq rights initiative of PEI. 

Today, we invite you to join us in celebrating two great years of progress, growth, and accomplishments – all in the name of protecting, preserving, and implementing the constitutionally entrenched rights of the Epekwitnewaq Mi’kmaq. We look forward to furthering these initiatives with another year of educating, learning, sharing and strengthening our relationships while connecting with more allies. 

We continue to move towards a better tomorrow and true reconciliation, together for generations to come as we build community understanding of our work and as we strive to create an appreciation for the legacy of Mi’kmaq culture and heritage

Msit No’kmaq | All My Relations

#LnuProud #Mikmaq #Epekwitk #Lnuey #MovingTowardsABetterTomorrow #Epekwitnewaq #EpekwitnewaqMikmaq

image.alt_text: Photo by Kendra Felicity Wheeler, BMus in St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador with @maskawitehew, and @coltpphotography. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.
image.caption:
As my fiancée and I drove around town yesterday, I saw houses donning the Canadian flag, some of them multiple flags and decorations, and my heart sank. 

Indigenous people have been crying out for justice, and this year, people have finally begun to listen, but some people still don’t understand. It took the discovery of mass graves, thousands of children’s bodies, for you to begin listening to us. We’ve been telling you for years: our children are missing, our women are going missing, we have no clean drinking water, you destroyed our culture, our language…WE ARE HURTING. But no one would listen. 

We are not Canada. Canada has given us trauma that is lasting for generations. Canada must admit that they have tried to erase us, that there was a genocide of our people, and they need to apologize and bring forward the truth. The Canadian Government and the Catholic Church must release all documentation regarding Residential Schools because we deserve TRUTH.

Real reconciliation cannot happen until the government listens to us and provides us with ways to heal.

Today is July 1st and I will not celebrate a country that has destroyed people like me.
.
.
My shirt was won in a giveaway from @maskawitehew! 🧡 Check them out, because their stuff is gorgeous.
.
.
Also, thank you so much to @coltpphotography for the photos!!! I can’t wait to keep sharing these shots. They turned out so well!!! 🧡🧡🧡
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

image.caption:
Since July 1st, people have stopped talking about the mass graves that CONTINUE to be found at Residential School sites. Innocent children died at the hands of the Catholic Church and the Canadian Government. Please, don’t stop talking about these children. They deserve to have their lives talked about. They did not deserve to die so young and be buried in unmarked mass graves. Keep talking.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Nadia Kaqtikew E’pit George in Native Land with @therezlifestyle. May be an image of one or more people and footwear.
image.caption:
1 2 3 #STOODIS 👊🏽
I think @theestallion says it best … “I'm a savage. 
Classy, bougie, ratchet.
Sassy, moody, nasty”

For those who don’t know me, my early life was a roller coaster, right from birth. Grew up a biker’s daughter, with parents who were still healing from their own trauma. I’d like to think I always had grace and an a kind spirit, but there is definitely the side of me that doesn’t back down. 

Life lessons are a funny thing, they’ve built me up and tore me down, but like a phoenix I’ve risen from the Ashes. 

So when it comes down to it, I’m always ready to step up for those I love, for injustice, myself and now for my people!
Also check out @therezlifestyle 
❤️🖤🤍💛
.
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Patti Catalano Dillon on October 06, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.
image.caption:
Boston Marathon five days to go.  I'm already getting butterflies as I'll be on the starting line!

I'm not running the Marathon.  I'm starting it!

Yes! Indeedie! I'm the Official Starter for the men's and women's Professional races for the Boston Marathon!  I'm over the moon.  What an incredible  joyous honor. And on Indigenous People's Day! 

A Mi'kmaq Tribal member starting the Boston Marathon. Brings tears to my heart. Who would have thought, huh?

The 125th running of the Boston Marathon is an exciting year for me and my family.  Yesterday zooming with the BAA to go over details, I learned that they are celebrating my 40th Anniversary of running the fastest time for an American woman  2 27 51. Yeahhhh.
Also the fastest Native American time for women. (still standing).

My goodness time flies. Forty years! I can't get over that one.

Forty years ago my life changed and so much for the better I couldn't have planned it.

Ellison "Tarzan" Brown's grandson Michael and I will be on a panel together to chat about our running experiences on Copley Plaza FanFest, Friday 1 PM

Come hear stories about running. About being an Indigenous runner. Hear some of the unrecorded history.

It'l be fun!

8 AM Saturday and Sunday Morning run with me and hubby.  Photo at 8:05. 

C'mon Newton, Brookline, let's "Run the land" . "Pray with our feet". "Reclaim the spirit of the land." PCD.

image.alt_text: Photo by Darren Calabrese on January 18, 2022. May be an image of child, standing, outdoors and tree.
image.caption:
Late last year, reporter Lindsay Jones and I were invited to a celebratory potluck recognizing the Mi’kmaq Grassroots Grandmothers’ successful seven-year fight against an Alton Gas project that would have pumped 10,000 cubic metres of brine into the mouth of the Stewiacke River in Nova Scotia. The project, to create subterranean caverns to store natural gas, would have greatly affected an estuary home to endangered striped bass with a worry it would have also polluted groundwater and the river system the Mi’kmaq had depended on for millennia.

The company eventually tapped out, posting a statement on its website lamenting that “the project has received mixed support, challenges, and experienced delay.”

The Alton Gas site on the river will be decommissioned, but the Mi’kmaq truckhouse erected will stay: it’s now a scared place of education, healing and meeting, and a reminder of the grandmothers’ and non-Indigenous supporters’ fight.

Published in @macleansmag with @lindsayleejones

First art fair done ✅. It was such a great experience! So many amazing works to see and be with and take in, exhibited beautifully. 🙌🏼🙌🏼 to the artists, galleries and to @art_toronto !! 🥳

My gratitude to @RBC’s acquisitions team for selecting Mntu I, II, & V (as shown in photo) to become part of RBC’s Art Collection. 💕 Very exciting! ✨✨

And thank you to Cathy, Susan, and Jennifer, for collecting Correlation Functions I-V, and to Scott and Susan for collecting Mntu IV. It was so nice to be able to meet with you and talk about the work in person 😊.

And to @galerielarochejoncas, to Louis and André, no words!! But many many feelings, 🙏🥰✨💕✨💕. A wonderful experience overall, that I am super grateful for!! ❤️

image.alt_text: Photo by Dawnland Movie on April 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'バ DAWNLAND VOICES AN ANTHOLOGY OF INDIGENOUS WRITING FROM NEW ENGLAND Edited by Siobhan Senier'.
image.caption:
Repost from @nulhegan_abenaki_tribe
•
As we celebrate Earth Week this year, we’d like to highlight a book we’ve recently been enjoying about connections to place - Dawnland Voices: An Anthology of Indigenous Writing From New England. The cover art on Dawnland Voices features the “Fiddlehead” purse by Rhonda Besaw, which is in the permanent collection of the Abbe Museum in Bar Harbor, Maine. From Besaw’s website: “Through beadwork, the reality of Abenaki survival can be shared and acknowledged. Through beadwork perhaps my brothers and sisters, my relatives will recognize a piece of who they are and who they were. Perhaps some will be inspired to learn more about their culture. Perhaps others will be inspired to pick up a needle and thread and tell their own story of survival.” This incredible book - a collection of Abenaki, Mi’kmaq, Maliseet, Passamaquoddy, Penobscot, Wampanoag, Narragansett, Mohegan, and Nipmuc narratives - reflects on our ties to place and celebrates Indigenous connections to Earth. #abenaki #nulheganabenaki #mikmaq #maliseet #passamaquoddy #penobscot #nipmuc #wampanoag #narragansett #mohegan #nativeamerican #firstnations #vermont #indigenousvoices #earthweek #turtleisland #nativeland #nativeamericanauthors #earthweek #earthday #nativeliterature #indigenousauthors

Blood quantum has been a touchy subject over the past year especially on social media. Every single person’s identity is unique and they should be proud of who they are and where they come from. So maybe just stop asking people how native they are and just be kind 🙂

image.alt_text: Photo by Jesse Benjamin in Halifax, Nova Scotia. May be an image of one or more people, people sitting, body of water and beach.
image.caption:
HOW MANY WOMEN IS TOO MANY??

Today (May 5) we wear red to raise awareness for #mmiwg Murdered and Missing Indigenous Women and Girls ❤️

I have seen debates on the stats here in Canada, some stating 6% and some as high as 24% of all murdered women are Indigenous women. But considering we only make up 2.5% of the Canadian population, this means we are 2-12X more likely to be targeted and killed than non-Indigenous women. In my mind the exact number is irrelevant….this is not ok. 

The MMIWG movement is often represented by a red handprint 🖐🏽 (as I have here on my earring) or by a red dress 👗 hanging in a window or a tree. 

To help raise awareness on this issue please consider:
1. Wearing Red
2. Doing a quick Google search or listening to someone with a story of how this crisis has affected their family
3. Spreading the word

📸 @kymber.rae 
#mmiwg2s #mmiwgawareness #wearred #indigenous #mikmaq #letsdobetter #strongresilientindigenous

image.alt_text: Photo by Mi'kmawey Debert Cultural Ctr on October 13, 2021. May be a cartoon of child and text that says 'MIKMAQ WIKEWIKU'S HISTORY MONTH OCTOBER "We are all treaty people."'.
image.caption:
ARE WE ALL TREATY PEOPLE?
Yes, all Canadians are treaty people! Because the treaties signed between the Mi'kmaq and the British Crown created rights and responsibilities for both groups - they are not one-sided agreements. 

We say, "WE ARE ALL TREATY PEOPLE," because we are all responsible to the treaties, and each of us has a role to play in upholding the rights and responsibilities that continue to this day.

To learn more about this year's Mi'kmaq History Month poster theme, visit the link in our bio.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Nadia Kaqtikew E’pit George on November 10, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, nature and tree.
image.caption:
Nujj (My Father),
Within the boundary of the trees I feel your protection, in the wind I hear your calming voice, and by the light of moon or sun I feel your love. 

@metallica was one of my dads favourite bands, it was also my first CD … yes I am that old lol and yes I still rock out to it.

I take my dad with me everywhere I  go, and as I walk in the living bounds of nature, this song always comes to mind 💜

“Oh, but I'll take my time anywhere
Free to speak my mind anywhere
And I'll redefine anywhere
Anywhere I roam
Where I lay my head is home, yeah
And the earth becomes my throne
I adapt to the unknown
Under wandering stars I've grown
By myself, but not alone
I ask no one
And my ties are severed clean
Less I have, the more I gain
Off the beaten path I reign
Roamer, wanderer, nomad, vagabond
Call me what you will” 

I will always be my daddy’s daughter and I’m so proud to say that.  Kesalul Nujj ❤️
.
.
.

NFS, I was gifted these beautiful porcupine quills by an Indigenous women last year when I was working at a gas station on the reserve. One of my favourite pairs I’ve made to date with so much love. Thank you @amlcrispo for giving me the opportunity to make these for you🪶🧡

image.alt_text: Photo by Frankfurter Buchmesse in Frankfurt, Germany with @livrescanadabooks, @kanadabotschaft, @eric_plamondon, @boersenverein, @canada.council, @canadafbm2021, @kanadafbm2021, @nirtak.enna, @lenosverlag, and @literatur2508. May be an image of 1 person and book.
image.caption:
Heute geht es mit #maplereads in die östliche Küstenregion Québecs: „Taqawan“ von Éric Plamondon 🍁🌊

Am 11. Juni 1981 kommt es zu einer unerwarteten Razzia im Gebiet der Mi´gmaq auf der Gaspésie-Halbinsel, im Zuge derer auch die 15jährige Océane Opfer der brutalen Gewalt der Polizisten wird. 
Der kanadische Ranger Yves Leclerc, die Französin Caroline und der Mi´gmaq William verfolgen die Spuren der Übeltäter und kämpfen darum, sie für ihre Taten zur Rechenschaft zu ziehen.
Obwohl "Taqawan" ein fiktionaler Roman ist, bleibt er damit doch sehr nah an der Realität: Immer wieder werden in Kanada indigene Frauen entführt, zudem sind sie zwölfmal häufiger Opfer sexueller Gewaltverbrechen als Frauen im kanadischen Durchschnitt. Zahlreiche Fälle werden aus Desinteresse der Behörden niemals aufgeklärt. Océanes Trauma steht damit stellvertretend für die Diskriminierung der indigenen Bevölkerung in Québec.
Zwischen die Schilderungen der Erfahrungen seiner Protagonist*innen fügt Éric Plamondon Exkurse über die Kultur und die mythische Vergangenheit der Mi´gmaq ein, schreibt über die Natur und Tierwelt und die ersten Begegnungen der First Nations mit den europäischen Einwander*innen. Dabei werden auch konfliktgeladene Diskurse wie die Frage nach den  Fischereirechten der vom Lachsfang lebenden, indigenen Bevölkerung im Hinblick auf die drohende Überfischung aufgegriffen.

„Taqawan“ ist ein außergewöhnliches Buch – spannend, abwechslungsreich und zugleich ungemein informativ. Es zeigt Kanada, Québec, aus mehreren Blickwinkeln und bringt damit die sozialen Unterschiede und strukturelle Unterdrückung zum Ausdruck, die auf eine lange Kolonisationsgeschichte zurückgehen und in der heutigen Gesellschaft noch immer existieren. Absolut empfehlenswert!

Annekatrin Stoll, Kommunikation Frankfurter Buchmesse

"Taqawan" von @eric_plamondon
Erschienen bei @lenosverlag
Übersetzt von Anne Thomas

image.alt_text: Photo by L'nuey PEI on November 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'EPEKWITNEWAQ MI'KMAQ N'in aq No'kmaq is a process to determine who is Epekwitnewaq Mi'kmaq (Mi' (Mi'kmaq of Epekwitk/PEI) and, therefore, who is an heir or a beneficiary to Mi'kmaq Aboriginal and Treaty Rights.'.
image.caption:
Epekwitnewaq Mi’kmaq
N’in aq No’kmaq is a process to determine who is Epekwitnewaq Mi’kmaq (Mi’kmaq of Epekwitk/PEI) and, therefore, who is an heir or a beneficiary to Mi’kmaq Aboriginal and Treaty Rights.

‘Epekwitk’ is the Mi’kmaq word for PEI.
’Epekwitnewaq’ means Islanders. 

During the month of November, we will be sharing a variety of terms to our social media that pertain to the Ni’n aq No’kmaq process like beneficiary, heir, Mi’kmaq Nation, and Epekwitnewaq Mi’kmaq.  Sharing these terms and what they mean will help build the same foundation and understanding for everyone. Education is key and will help us take more important steps in moving towards a better tomorrow.

image.alt_text: Photo by Mi'kmawey Debert Cultural Ctr on October 14, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'Is it Mi'kmaq? 7 Or Mi'kmaw? Mi'kmawey Debert CULTURAL CENTRE'.
image.caption:
Is it Mi'kmaq or Mi'kmaw?

The word Mi'kmaw (mee gah maw) has three uses. It's the adjectival form of the word Mi'kmaq (mee gah mah), for example, "Mi'kmaw communities," and the singular noun form such as "Jane, a Mi'kmaw, crossed the street." We also use this form to describe our language, as in, "we speak Mi'kmaw." The word Mi'kmaq is the plural noun form as in, "the Mi'kmaq are indigenous."

To learn more, visit our website at the link in our bio.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Adalie on July 31, 2021. May be an image of nature, body of water and bridge.
image.caption:
Promenade dans le parc de Greenwich sur la côte nord-est de l’Île-du-Prince-Édouard (#Epekwitk), avec toute sa verdure, son grand étang, et ses dunes de sable à l’infini 🌾

Un paysage en constant changement, modelé par le vent et les courants. Un endroit riche, par sa faune et sa flore, mais aussi son histoire, car il était l’un des premiers lieux de rassemblement de communautés Mi’kmaq sur l’île, il y a plusieurs milliers d’années. Aujourd’hui, quelques organismes travaillent activement à défendre les droits des communautés Mi’kmaq d’Epekwitk (@lnuey.ca), et instaurer une variété de programmes éducatifs (@mcpeicommunications) pour célébrer et partager l’héritage culturel des Mi’kmaq aux personnes autochtones et non-autochtones, un pas à la fois vers la réconciliation. 

#mikmaq #autochtone
